awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Time Dependence of Seismic Parameters in Hawaii
awd_abstract_narration:
Hawaii is one of the most seismically active regions in the world. For the past few decades, it has been used as a natural laboratory for studying the interactions between seismic and magmatic processes. The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Hawaiian Volcano Observatory (HVO) has an extensive network of instruments to investigate in real-time the ongoing activity on the island of Hawaii. Yet, much less attention has been paid to seismic-parameter temporal variations. These variations have considerable potential for quantifying the activity and possibly forecasting major destructive events. Here, the researchers calculate seismic parameters for all events in the Hawaii island recorded over the past 33 years. They analyze their time dependence and examine both the long-term variations and the short-term changes before and after significant events. One goal is to evaluate to what extend crustal stress changes explained by past events are predictive of future large events. The team also investigates whether there is a long-term evolution in activity. This project provides support and training for several graduate and undergraduate students. Its outcomes have direct implications for forecasting seismic and volcanic events in Hawaii island. The three-year award was co-funded by NSF Prediction of and Resilience against Extreme Events (PREEVENTS) program.

The project aims to complete a comprehensive search for temporal variations in seismic parameters and gain new insights into the interactions between seismic and magmatic processes. The investigated parameters include seismicity rate, b-value, fault plane solutions, coda Q, velocity and anisotropy structure, and near-source Vp/Vs ratios. The work exploits digital seismic data recorded by the USGS HVO seismic stations. It leverages on available 3-D seismic velocity and attenuation models, earthquake relocations, and focal solutions provided by prior studies. Results quantify potential variations in seismic parameters before and after magmatic (eruptions and intrusions) and non-magmatic (earthquakes and slow-slip) events. They also evaluate potential long-lasting changes over the past 33 years.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project are to complete a comprehensive search for temporal variations in seismic parameters in Hawaii and to gain new insights into the interactions of seismic and magmatic processes using a number of proven techniques. Our work was based on the seismic data originated from the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Hawaiian Volcano Observatory (HVO) and the results obtained by prior NSF-supported studies (Lin et al., 2014a,b, 2015b,a; Li and Lin, 2016; Lin and Okubo, 2016). During this project, we investigated the spatiotemporal variations in earthquake distribution, focal solution, in situ Vp/Vs ratio and seismic velocity with a focus on the recent 2018 Kilauea volcano eruption. We also examined the velocity variations corresponding to the 2020 Kilauea eruption and systematic long-lasting changes in Hawaii. We have detected new long-period events before the 2018 Kilauea eruption and updated the earthquake relocation catalog for the Island of Hawaii based on 33 years of HVO seismic data. This project has resulted in three peer-reviewed publications (Ge et al., 2019; Lin and Okubo, 2020; Lin and Shearer, 2021) and one book chapter on volcano-tectonic earthquake monitoring (Lin, 2023). This project supported three Ph.D. students at the University of Miami. The research results were presented at numerous national conferences and also in PI Lin's IRIS/SSA Distinguished Lecture.


Last Modified: 10/11/2023
Modified by: Guoqing Lin

Images (1 of )
  • Relocation results for earthquakes from July 1, 2015 to August 31, 2018. (a) Map view of the 46,053 waveform cross-correlation relocations, starting from the three-dimensional locations. (b, c) Depth distributions of the relocation seismicity in (a) along profiles A-B and C-D.
    Guoqing Lin
    Copyrighted
    Guoqing Lin
    Relocated seismicity during the 2018 Kilauea eruption
  • (Left) Distribution of the well-resolved focal mechanisms for the background seismicity (events from July 1, 2015 to April 10, 2018). (Right) Distribution of the well-resolved focal mechanisms for the 2018 Kilauea sequence (events from April 11, 2018 to August 31, 2018).
    Guoqing Lin
    Copyrighted
    Guoqing Lin
    Focal solutions during the 2018 Kilauea eruption
  • In situ Vp/Vs ratios for similar earthquake clusters in the background seismicity (left) and the 2018 Kilauea sequence (right). (a) Map view. (b, c) Depth distributions.
    Guoqing Lin
    Copyrighted
    Guoqing Lin
    Vp/Vs ratios during the 2018 Kilauea eruption
  • (a-c) Seismic velocity variations from January 1 to August 31 2018 at 3 stations in the summit area of Kilauea volcano. (d-f) Seismic velocity variations at 3 stations in the East Rift Connector. (g-i) Seismic velocity variations at 3 stations in the Middle East Rift Zone.
    Guoqing Lin
    Copyrighted
    Guoqing Lin
    Seismic velocity variations from January 1 to August 31 2018
  • (a-e) Seismic velocity variations corresponding to the 2020 Kilauea volcano eruption, calculated by using ambient noise autocorrelation for 5 HVO stations in Kilauea's summit area. (f) Station locations.
    Guoqing Lin
    Guoqing Lin
    Seismic velocity variations corresponding to the 2020 Kilauea volcano eruption
